I'm with Kaku here. in another of his videos he makes this distinction 
between the personal God and the God of simplicity. The personal God is 
what religious people believe in, the God that will answer your prayers, 
the God who knows you and everyone in the world, the God that loves 
everyone, yet punishes you if you are evil. very paradoxical, very 
confusing. Personally, like Kaku, I believe in the God of simplicity. Not 
necessarily a God that we can observe with our own eyes, but perhaps a God 
that governs the several dimensions above us, the God that is beyond the 
multiverse. I believe God is math. He's got this universe, and all other 
possible universes, down to a science. And though we'd like to believe that 
one day we'll have a single equation that can "read the mind of God," I 
think those are high aspirations. No matter how far we develop mathematics 
and physics, I don't think we can ever fully understand God, coincidences, 
inter-dimensional time, the afterlife, and separate universes from our own.﻿

Michio Kaku says that God could be a mathematician: "The mind of God we 
believe is cosmic music, the music of strings resonating through 11 
dimensional hyperspace. That is the mind of God."

Video Transcript:
Some people ask the question "Of what good is math?" What is the 
relationship between math and physics? Well, sometimes math leads. 
Sometimes physics leads. Sometimes they come together because, of course, 
there's a use for the mathematics. For example, in the 1600s Isaac Newton 
asked a simple question: if an apple falls then does the moon also fall? 
That is perhaps one of the greatest questions ever asked by a member of 
Homo sapiens since the six million years since we parted ways with the 
apes. If an apple falls, does the moon also fall? 

Isaac Newton said yes, the moon falls because of the Inverse Square Law. So 
does an apple. He had a unified theory of the heavens, but he didn't have 
the mathematics to solve the falling moon problem. So what did he do? He 
invented calculus. So calculus is a direct consequence of solving the 
falling moon problem. In fact, when you learn calculus for the first time, 
what is the first thing you do? The first thing you do with calculus is you 
calculate the motion of falling bodies, which is exactly how Newton 
calculated the falling moon, which opened up celestial mechanics.

So here is a situation where math and physics were almost conjoined like 
Siamese twins, born together for a very practical question, how do you 
calculate the motion of celestial bodies? Then here comes Einstein asking a 
different question and that is, what is the nature and origin of gravity? 
Einstein said that gravity is nothing but the byproduct of curved space. So 
why am I sitting in this chair? A normal person would say I'm sitting in 
this chair because gravity pulls me to the ground, but Einstein said no, 
no, no, there is no such thing as gravitational pull; the earth has curved 
the space over my head and around my body, so space is pushing me into my 
chair. So to summarize Einstein's theory, gravity does not pull; space 
pushes. But, you see, the pushing of the fabric of space and time requires 
differential calculus. That is the language of curved surfaces, 
differential calculus, which you learn in fourth year calculus.

So again, here is a situation where math and physics were very closely 
combined, but this time math came first. The theory of curved surfaces came 
first. Einstein took that theory of curved surfaces and then imported it 
into physics.

Now we have string theory. It turns out that 100 years ago math and physics 
parted ways. In fact, when Einstein proposed special relativity in 1905, 
that was also around the time of the birth of topology, the topology of 
hyper-dimensional objects, spheres in 10, 11, 12, 26, whatever dimension 
you want, so physics and mathematics parted ways. Math went into hyperspace 
and mathematicians said to themselves, aha, finally we have found an area 
of mathematics that has no physical application whatsoever. Mathematicians 
pride themselves on being useless. They love being useless. It's a badge of 
courage being useless, and they said the most useless thing of all is a 
theory of differential topology and higher dimensions.

Well, physics plotted along for many decades. We worked out atomic bombs. 
We worked out stars. We worked out laser beams, but recently we discovered 
string theory, and string theory exists in 10 and 11 dimensional 
hyperspace. Not only that, but these dimensions are super. They're super 
symmetric. A new kind of numbers that mathematicians never talked about 
evolved within string theory. That's how we call it "super string theory." 
Well, the mathematicians were floored. They were shocked because all of a 
sudden out of physics came new mathematics, super numbers, super topology, 
super differential geometry. 

All of a sudden we had super symmetric theories coming out of physics that 
then revolutionized mathematics, and so the goal of physics we believe is 
to find an equation perhaps no more than one inch long which will allow us 
to unify all the forces of nature and allow us to read the mind of God. And 
what is the key to that one inch equation? Super symmetry, a symmetry that 
comes out of physics, not mathematics, and has shocked the world of 
mathematics. But you see, all this is pure mathematics and so the final 
resolution could be that God is a mathematician. And when you read the mind 
of God, we actually have a candidate for the mind of God. The mind of God 
we believe is cosmic music, the music of strings resonating through 11 
dimensional hyperspace. That is the mind of God.﻿

top_comment.text:
What will atheist say when there is proof of God?

We all need to wake up from this delusion we are feeding our mind. 

String Theory is the only theory that can explain all phenomenons.

A Theory of Everything?

One of the crowning achievements of 20th century science is that all the 
laws of physics, at a fundamental level, can be summarized by just two 
formalisms: (1) Einstein’s theory of gravity, which gives us a cosmic 
description of the very large, i.e. galaxies, black holes and the Big Bang, 
and (2) the quantum theory, which gives us a microscopic description of the 
very small, i.e. the microcosm of sub-atomic particles and radiation. But 
the supreme irony, and surely one of Nature’s cosmic jokes, is that they 
look bewilderingly different; even the world’s greatest physicists, 
including Einstein and Heisenberg, have failed to unify these into one. The 
two theories use different mathematics and different physical principles to 
describe the universe in their respective domains, the cosmic and the 
microscopic. Fortunately, we now have a candidate for this theory. (In 
fact, it is the only candidate. Scores of rival proposals have all been 
shown to be inconsistent.) It’s called “superstring theory,” and almost 
effortlessly unites gravity with a theory of radiation, which is required 
to solve the problem of quantum wormholes. The superstring theory can 
explain the mysterious quantum laws of sub-atomic physics by postulating 
that sub-atomic particles are really just resonances or vibrations of a 
tiny string. The vibrations of a violin string correspond to musical notes; 
likewise the vibrations of a superstring correspond to the particles found 
in nature. The universe is then a symphony of vibrating strings. An added 
bonus is that, as a string moves in time, it warps the fabric of space 
around it, producing black holes, wormholes, and other exotic solutions of 
Einstein’s equations. Thus, in one stroke, the superstring theory unites 
both the theory of Einstein and quantum physics into one coherent, 
compelling picture.﻿

The original, or root, meaning of "evidence" is a distinct thing that 
infers the existence of something not seen, or not readily perceptible. For 
example, a painting infers the existence, or former existence, of a 
painter. There are numerous other examples, like a human footprint 
inferring the past presence of a human being. Any appearance presupposes a 
substance responsible for this particular appearance. The theist argument 
that a cosmic appearance of observable orderly complexity infers a 
purposeful designer, whether perceptible or imperceptible, existent or 
previously existent, is perfectly in keeping with the meaning of evidence.

proof of some type of higher power, which God (s) would this be proof of?

know if it's any god any human has even conceived of? Why for you make the 
assumption that it proves your god over others? Or even your version of god 
over another's version of the same god?"

Well, and there's the thing, in my view.
I don't really care IF "God" exists.
I care WHICH god exists (if any).
If it's the god of the bible as I understand him, well screw him. I didn't 
reject Christianity over the existence question.
I rejected it because all I understand about morality tells me that god is 
a monster, and worshiping a monster would be an immoral thing to do.

I am not an Asatruar because I believe the gods exist. I am an Asatruar 
because the morality of the teachings is up to my standards, and I don't 
have to engage in any apologetics to see the morality. Exist or not, I 
would not honor the gods if I didn't believe they are moral. In fact, some 
are not (Loki is a good example) and I do not honor those.

So, yes. If proof of a god is found, my reaction would be to ask which god 
and what he expects of us.
.

When paraphrasing, be careful not to misconstrue the other person: I wrote 
that science was *founded* on empty assertions ("if an apple falls, does 
the Moon also fall?"), *not* made out of it. Please reread my previous 
post; you should find my explanation perfectly aligns with your definition 
of a paradox. Unless of course you can show me otherwise. 

Now, the explanation is moderately simple! Anything descendant from human 
culture (i.e. fairies and perpetual motion machines if you will) despite 
being *impossible to conceive* (unless you have one, in which case I'd 
quite like to see), are quite *possible to fathom*. I can imagine what a 
fairy would look like, the nature of its abilities, etc.

God by definition must transcend the realm of humanity entirely (i.e. How 
an illustrator holding the pencil would to a stick man). And the only thing 
that humans can't fathom, is infinity. Eternity. Omnipotence. These 
*concepts*, not ideas, cannot be defined by human logic. Thus, to accept 
the concept of God (not what God is, else you could fathom an aspect of 
God, which contravenes the parameters that define 'God') is to acknowledge 
that you cannot comprehend such a being, and believe that one as such must 
exist. A paradox: as humans tend to deny that which we cannot experience, 
as admitted by yourself. 

I look forward to well scrutinised and thought over response.

+ATROFlAR Physics is cumulative like math, no one expects you to jump into

top_comment.text:
In all of Kakus brightness, I differ from his view of mathematicians. 
Albert Einstein once said: "pure mathematics is, in its way, the poetry of 
logical ideas". That said, it's not that we pride ourselves when being 
useless, it's that we simply don't care (that much) for the physical 
universe as we do for the abstract universe of logic.

There is some truth in his statement (not from my perspective but from 
colleges and mathematics researchers). When there is a big breakthrough in 
mathematics (some important result was published) and it happened to have a 
lot of applications, not only in pure physics but also in chemistry, 
computer sciences, economy etc. we celebrate this but not get amazed 
(mainly because we don't understand them). What it bothers most in the math 
community is the fact that what receives most ajttention and credit from 
the scientific community (and by media) is the application itself, there is 
nearly no attention to that researcher that made a mathematical discovery 
from which the application ramified.﻿

comments.text:
+Ami Blackwelder I can say with 99.9 certainty that there is some sort of 
Creator. You can't just have everything magically arranging itself then 
having the first living cell magically forming then magically replicating 
at the same time then we magically evolving from bacteria on the planet 
that shouldn't mathematically be here in the universe that came out of 
nothing? That is a joke. But that is what some people actually believe. The 
ones who have been brainwashed by pseudoscience and havent look at the 
evidence and data themselves.

You see, the probability of even one single protein molecule consisting of 
200 amino acids arising spontaneously by chance is 1 in 10 raised to power 
of 200. This is calculated by raising 20 (the number of different types 
amino acids available) to the power of 200 (the number of amino acids in 
the protein chain). Even if the whole universe was packed with all the 
correct amino acids combining frantically for billions of years, it would 
not produce even one such protein molecule let alone produce a living cell. 

Let's now put this in its larger context.  Proteins are 'made' by genes in 
the cell.

 The average human gene consists of 3000 bases, but sizes vary greatly, 
with the largest known human gene being dystrophin at 2.4 million bases.

The total number of human genes is estimated at 30,000.

 The human genome has some 3 billion DNA base pairs. Except for mature red 
blood cells, all human cells contain a complete genome!
 The constellation of all proteins in a cell is called its proteome. Unlike 
the relatively unchanging genome, the dynamic proteome changes from minute 
to minute in response to tens of thousands of intra- and extracellular 
environmental signals. A protein’s chemistry and behavior are specified by 
the gene sequence and by the number and identities of other proteins made 
in the same cell at the same time and with which it associates and reacts.

Finally, It is estimated that the human body may contain over two million 
different proteins, each with a unique function.

There is no chance that the human body could have come about by 
chance....The chances of the human body arising by chance is zero.

comments.text:
Something very interesting to me:

It seems like everything conforms in nature. We can see this in physics and 
biology, and the more it conforms, the more structurally complex it becomes 
and the less functionally powerful it becomes.


Example:

Biology: the single cell can be many things, but once it is part of the 
heart, it acts as part of the heart only. 

Physics: Atoms can become many things, but once they become a molecule and 
then matter, they are more restricted.

Virtual particles pop in, but if the particle is a quark the majority of 
virtual particles that pop in are quarks, though some might be other things 
like gluons or photons. But this doesn't effect the quark since the 
majority keep it as is (my understanding may be missing some info here)

But my point is that it seems like even in the most fundamental forms of 
nature, nature is busy conforming and the more it does the more complex in 
structure it becomes and as it does this the more it losses functional 
power.

Just something I've been noticing in patterns.

که من نقد می‌کنم. من احترام هم حتی نگه نمی‌دارم وقتی می‌بینم این دین در 
جایی انسانی رو از حقش محروم می‌کنه و یا کسی رو سنگسار می‌کنه. مصطفی جان 
اعتقاداتی که از حوزهٔ یک شخص خارج میشه و به دیگری تجاوز میکنه دیگه شخصی 
نیست و باید به نقد کشیده بشه. من این کار رو می‌کنم وگرنه روزی میرسه که 
تهدیدش رو برام عملی می‌کنه. هرچند همونجور که شاید خودت هم بدونی همین الانش 
هم من اصلا مصون نیستم. توی همین پلاس افرادی بودند که من رو تهدید کردند و چه 
بسا اگه دستشون بهم می‌رسید من رو ناکار می‌کردند. هر چند من تمام تلاشم رو 
می‌کنم که در کنترل اعصابم رو از دست ندم به اعتقادات توهین نکنم ولی بعضی 
چیزها رو می‌بینم و کنترلم رو از دست می‌دم. می‌بینم که دینی بر میخ خدایی که 
وجودش اثبات نشده میکوبه و دیگران رو زیر فشار قرار می‌ده، حرصم می‌گیره.
مصطفی جان من یه سوال ازت می‌کنم. آیا اگه من بیام گردن خودت یا عزیزت رو به 
خاطر دگراندیشی بزنم عمل شنیعی انجام دادم یا بیام و این گردن زدن تو رو مسخره 
کنم و یا حتی بهش توهین کنم. باید قبول کنی زمانی که یک عمل وقیحی توسط باوری 
اشاعه پیدا می‌کنه، توهین و مسخره کردنش واقعا در مقابل، اونقدرها زشت و زننده 
به نظر نمیاد.

top_comment.text:
When you think about it, only the narrow-minded can't get their heads 
around the concept of God. Imagine, let's say, a stick-man that you have 
drawn. You perceive it to have no consciousness, no reality. It is a 
drawing after all.

Now let's suppose that stick-man was sentient. To the stick-man, your 
humanly influence transcends the mere 2D realm in which he dwells, for you 
cannot draw a stick-man with your fingers alone. Rather, the pencil is what 
the stick-man does observe. Through it's graphite tip and rubber end, you 
shape and define his reality according to your handiwork.

Through this pencil the stick-man's entire reality is both created and 
destroyed; when you draw with it, the stick-man perceives new life and 
matter being formed before him. When you erase, he witnesses the cataclysm 
and obliteration that ensues. To the stick-man, you are not real; but the 
power of the pencil... it is the single inexplicable phenomenon. The 
pencil has the power to give, and take away. It is a 'god'.

Whether the stick-man believes in this pencil, or whether you have designed 
him with it, remains a mystery. He may try to better understand this 
pencil's power with the sciences of his 2D realm; we can not tell, nor do 
we care. For as the illustrator, we are the beginning. And the end.

And so it is, with God.﻿
top_comment.author: Ytremz

In the end, we can never experience the power of our illustrator, which I

Interesting idea. But tell me, what would be the chance of that pot-hole 
being the only rain-filled pot-hole that it could find? Then, what would be 
the chance that this specific Sun of all the near unquantifiable stars in 
existence happened to exist at the right time and place to create said 
sentient pot-hole? And then finally tell me, of all the possible universes 
and timelines, what is the chance that this universe had existed long 
enough to allow the formation of those unquantifiable amount of stars that 
led to this Sun contributing to the creation of said sentient pot-hole?

an idea both incredulousness and meaningfulness.

comments.text:
The concept of God is, fairly safe to say, disprovable. Similar to your 
analogy of stick figures though I am sure. Deism is something I encounter 
regularly and I always attempt to be reasonable and accepting. I however am 
a lot less a fan of those who adopt theologies which result in moral 
absolutes. 

But since we are going to give inanimate objects a consciousness, here is 
one for you.

A pothole forms on a dusty road on a hot summers day, that evening it rains 
and a puddle fills that pothole. So naturally the pothole thinks, "Hey this 
hole was made for me!".

It may later learn facts that discredit that. Like meeting another pothole.

Yet the concept of design was much more alluring than the concept of chance 
simply becomes it gave purpose to one.
comments.author: Shaun Westley

captions.text:
Some people ask the question of what good
is math?  What is the relationship between

math and physics?  Well, sometimes math leads. 
Sometimes physics leads.  Sometimes they

come together because, of course, there’s
a use for the mathematics.  For example,

in the 1600s Isaac Newton asked a simple question:
if an apple falls then does the moon also

fall?  That is perhaps one of the greatest
questions ever asked by a member of Homo sapiens

since the six million years since we parted
ways with the apes.  If an apple falls, does

the moon also fall? 
Isaac Newton said yes, the moon falls because

of the Inverse Square Law.  So does an apple. 
He had a unified theory of the heavens, but

he didn't have the mathematics to solve the
falling moon problem.  So what did he do?

He invented calculus.  So calculus is a direct
consequence of solving the falling moon problem.

In fact, when you learn calculus for the first
time, what is the first thing you do?  The

first thing you do with calculus is you calculate
the motion of falling bodies, which is exactly

how Newton calculated the falling moon, which
opened up celestial mechanics.

So here is a situation where math and physics
were almost conjoined like Siamese twins,

born together for a very practical question,
how do you calculate the motion of celestial

bodies?  Then here comes Einstein asking
a different question and that is, what is

the nature and origin of gravity?  Einstein
said that gravity is nothing but the byproduct

of curved space.  So why am I sitting in
this chair?  A normal person would say I'm

sitting in this chair because gravity pulls
me to the ground, but Einstein said no, no,

no, there is no such thing as gravitational
pull; the earth has curved the space over

my head and around my body, so space is pushing
me into my chair.  So to summarize Einstein's

theory, gravity does not pull; space pushes. 
But, you see, the pushing of the fabric of

space and time requires differential calculus. 
That is the language of curved surfaces, differential

calculus, which you learn in fourth year calculus.
So again, here is a situation where math and

physics were very closely combined, but this
time math came first.  The theory of curved

surfaces came first.  Einstein took that
theory of curved surfaces and then imported

it into physics.
Now we have string theory.  It turns out

that 100 years ago math and physics parted
ways.  In fact, when Einstein proposed special

relativity in 1905, that was also around the
time of the birth of topology, the topology

of hyper-dimensional objects, spheres in 10,
11, 12, 26, whatever dimension you want, so

physics and mathematics parted ways.  Math
went into hyperspace and mathematicians said

to themselves, aha, finally we have found
an area of mathematics that has no physical

application whatsoever.  Mathematicians pride
themselves on being useless.  They love being

useless.  It's a badge of courage being useless,
and they said the most useless thing of all

is a theory of differential topology and higher
dimensions.

Well, physics plotted along for many decades. 
We worked out atomic bombs.  We worked out

stars.  We worked out laser beams, but recently
we discovered string theory, and string theory

exists in 10 and 11 dimensional hyperspace. 
Not only that, but these dimensions are super.

They're super symmetric.  A new kind of numbers
that mathematicians never talked about evolved

within string theory.  That's how we call
it “super string theory.”  Well, the

mathematicians were floored.  They were shocked
because all of a sudden out of physics came

new mathematics, super numbers, super topology,
super differential geometry.

All of a sudden we had super symmetric theories
coming out of physics that then revolutionized

mathematics, and so the goal of physics we
believe is to find an equation perhaps no

more than one inch long which will allow us
to unify all the forces of nature and allow

us to read the mind of God.  And what is
the key to that one inch equation?  Super

symmetry, a symmetry that comes out of physics,
not mathematics, and has shocked the world

of mathematics.  But you see, all this is
pure mathematics and so the final resolution

could be that God is a mathematician.  And
when you read the mind of God, we actually

have a candidate for the mind of God.  The
mind of God we believe is cosmic music, the

music of strings resonating through 11 dimensional
hyperspace.  That is the mind of God.

title: Michio Kaku: Is God a Mathematician?
